newsitem.title: UK: UK government looks again at soccer tragedy.
newsitem.headline: UK government looks again at soccer tragedy.

text.p: Families of 96 football fans who died in a crush at a soccer match in 1989 have been invited to meet Britain's new interior minister on Monday, just before he makes a statement to parliament on the disaster.

The invitation from Jack Straw, confirmed by a spokesman at his Home Office department, led to media speculation on Thursday that Straw may order a new inquiry into the tragedy at the Hillsborough stadium in the northern England town of Sheffield.
A television documentary screened last December claimed to have uncovered new evidence about the tragedy, which happened at a cup semi-final match between Nottingham Forest and Liverpool.
The programme revived calls for a re-examination of police conduct at Hillsborough and greater compensation for relatives of the dead, who were all Liverpool fans.
But Straw's predecessor at the Home Office, Michael Howard, said he would not reopen the inquiry unless he was convinced a new probe was in the public interest.
The Home Office spokesman said he could not comment on Straw's view ahead of his statement to parliament on Monday.
